title.narrative: RELIGIOUS FREEDOM INITIATIVE PLUS (RFI+)

description.narrative: In partnership with a local organisation, Loka Ahlinn (LA), Mercy Corps is implementing a two-year €200,000 cost expansion project entitled Religious Freedom Initiative Plus (RFI+) in Myanmar’s Magway and Sagaing regions. This proposed project complements existing interventions MC is implementing in Rakhine State, Mon State, Kayin State, Mandalay Region, Southern Shan State, and Western Bago Region with the support of the U.S Department of State Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor.

The project will link the human rights defenders (HRDs) already trained by MC to youth. The latter are the most active users of social media, where rumours and hate speech about religious minorities are widely circulated. The HRDs will work with youth groups to: 1) develop innovative and participatory short form documentaries for religious or belief awareness campaigns; 2) organize sports events which also includes awareness raising messages about individual freedom to express their identity, as informed by religious or other beliefs; 3) provide communities with information on laws that hinder freedom of religion and belief to amplify the voices of local HRDs and moderate leaning religious leaders. The activities will ensure the participation of women and girls, while addressing constraints by engaging male gatekeepers.

activity-date.narrative: The original end date was 31 October 2020, but the project was granted a 1-month no-cost extension.

job-title.narrative: Senior Programme Officer for South and East Asia
Assistant Programme Officer for South and East Asia

sector.narrative: Building support for legal reforms that will enhance religious freedom and the protection of religious minority rights in Myanmar.

title.narrative: RFI+ Annual Narrative Progress Report - Year 1
Mercy Corps Europe 2018 Annual Report
Output 2.4: 11 training sessions on sport for religious minority rights conducted

description.narrative: During the normal trainings, team coaches will include modules of the training in their daily trainings.

comment.narrative: 29 training sessions were conducted in Q5, Year 2. One additional training session was conducted in Q6.

description.narrative: 20 teams bringing together 600 players complete 11 session trainings on sport for religious minority rights.

comment.narrative: There were 607 participants during the football training sessions conducted in Q5, Year 2, with a further 20 participants for the training session in Q6.

title.narrative: Output 2.4c: # of women team members attending the training sessions on sport for religious minority rights

comment.narrative: Of the 607 football training participants in Q5, Year 2, 175 identified as female, while an additional 29 identified as neither male nor female.

title.narrative: Output 2.2: 15 teams identified and formed to participate in the sport for change activities, including the tournament

description.narrative: LA will identify existing teams, or where required, mobilise young people to form teams of 20-30 people, possibly from different religions to be part of the sports program.

title.narrative: Output 2.2b: # of women participants in the sports teams

comment.narrative: Of the football players, 175 identified as female, while an additional 29 identified as neither male nor female.

title.narrative: Output 2.2a: # of sport teams identified to participate in the sport for change activities, including the tournament

comment.narrative: The trained football captains have conducted training sessions in their local communities (29 in Q5, 1 in Q6). It is expected those who participated in the training sessions will now form teams.

title.narrative: Output 2.1: One sport curriculum for religious minority rights adapted

description.narrative: Mercy Corps will adapt its sports for peace curriculum used in Kenya to strengthen the ability of local actors, especially youths to understand the root causes of abuse of religious minorities and to promote inter-faith dialogue and protection of freedom of religion and belief at the community level.

title.narrative: Output 2.1a: # of sport curriculum for religious minority rights available

comment.narrative: The curriculum was adapted and translated from English to the Myanmar language in Year 1 Q4

title.narrative: Output 1.4: One cross learning event conducted with HRDs and activists from Magway and Sagaing regions

description.narrative: Recognising the role of experiential, peer-to-peer learning in knowledge acquisition and skills-building among adult learners, MC will convene trained HRDs in Two (2) regional local and One (1) cross-learning events. The cross-learning events will provide a safe space for bringing diverse HRDs together to learn about the experiences, challenges, and concerns of their peers from other religious communities and to share effective awareness-raising techniques

title.narrative: Output 1.4a: # of cross learning events conducted

comment.narrative: Local cross learning event conducted in Year 1, Q4

title.narrative: Output 2.5: 15 teams take part in awareness raising tournament

description.narrative: Reversing laws, actions and practices that abuse religious minorities will require the building of a large constituency of people with a common understanding of what it means to respect the freedom of religion and belief. This can only be achieved by creating spaces where majority Buddhists and minority Muslims and Christians, among others can interact freely and begin to appreciate diversity. Sport provide a shared space in which people of different faith and ethnic background can interact freely and judge each other by the strength of their character, rather than their religious affiliation. The tournament will bring together all the teams that would have completed the 11 session trainings together for games, networking and to raise awareness on the

title.narrative: Output 1.5: One national cross-learning event organized at the national level

description.narrative: This learning event will bring together the local HRDs from Magway and Sagaing regions with their counter-parts from other parts of the country

title.narrative: Output 1.5a: # of national cross-learning events conducted

comment.narrative: Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, it was not possible to conduct the national cross learning event. Instead, Mercy Corps arranged and facilitated a special online talk on FoRB in Q7, with 35 participants

title.narrative: Output 1.3: 1,350 IEC materials produced and distributed

description.narrative: To bolster our awareness creating efforts, we will use IEC materials to create demand, curiosity and questioning of national legal frameworks, actions and practices that discriminate against religious minorities. The materials will be formulated and executed in a manner that will trigger debate, educate and persuade the public to realise their roles and responsibilities in protecting the rights of individual freedom of religion and belief and the benefits accruing from protecting others Human Rights.

title.narrative: Output 1.3a: # of IEC materials distributed to the community

comment.narrative: 1380 IEC materials distributed in Q3, Year 1 335 IEC materials distributed in Q5, Year 2 285 copies were distributed during the documentary show activities

title.narrative: Output 1.1: 15 Human Rights Defenders from Magway and Sagaing regions trained

description.narrative: To promote increased and ethical reporting on issues related to religious freedom and religious minority rights, LA will conduct two two-day workshops reaching 15 journalists in the two new regions. Participants will include reporters, op-ed columnists, and traditional and online media editors from the two regions. The training curriculum, developed with input from media experts and HRDs knowledgeable about religious minority rights, will cover topics including national and international laws protecting religious freedom, the role of religious freedom in a diverse democracy, ethical and unbiased reporting principles and strategies, and dealing with the risks of censorship.

title.narrative: Output 1.1a: # of trainings completed for grassroots HRD from Magway and Sagaing regions

comment.narrative: 15 human rights defenders were provided training on Freedom of Religious Belief in Q3 Yr1

title.narrative: Output 1.2: 45 awareness-raising events conducted.

description.narrative: With support from LA, each HRD will conduct at least three awareness-raising events in their community, for a total at least 45 awareness-raising events reaching at least 1, 350 people (600 Buddhists, 750 religious minorities). Each HRD will develop an awareness-raising plan tailored to their context, accounting for factors like personal safety, audience attitudes toward religious minorities (in the case of Buddhist HRDs), and concerns about visible rights initiatives (in the case of religious minority HRDs).

title.narrative: Output 1.2a: # of awareness raising events conducted in different locations

comment.narrative: The 45 awareness-raising events were conducted in Year 1 Q4.
